title: pika: A lightweight package for evaluating correlation between time series
text: pika lightweight package enables easily estimating optimal lag rolling corrleation two time series. package dveloped use epidemiological data mobility data, can used generally time series. main utility package ability determine quantities interest grouping variable, rolling correlation two time series different locations. vignette goes different functionality pika epidemiological context, namely determining optimal lag rolling correlation estimates reproduction number (average number new cases generated single case) mobility within population within different regions China COVID-19 pandemic.

title: pika: A lightweight package for evaluating correlation between time series
text: pika contains several example data sets data/ directory can used run package functions. example data sets include 1. Daily confirmed cases COVID-19 different provinces China (china_case_data) 2. Daily within-city movement data provinces 1 (exante_movement_data) case data daily confirmed confirmed cases different provinces China 16 January 24 March 2020 dashboard maintained Chinese Center Disease Prevention Control (CCDC) [1]. CCDC dashboard collates numbers confirmed cases reported national local health commissions province mainland China, Hong Kong SAR Macau SAR. Confirmed cases defined suspected cases, epidemiological links /clinical symptoms, detected SARS-CoV-2 PCR tests. However, Hubei province, clinically diagnosed cases additionally included 12 19 February. daily within-city movement data, used proxy economic activity, available 1 January 24 March 2020 major metropolitan cities within province mainland China, Hong Kong SAR, Macau SAR. data, provided Exante Data Inc [2], measured travel activity relative 2019 average (excluding Lunar New Year). underlying data based near real-time people movement statistics Baidu.

title: pika: A lightweight package for evaluating correlation between time series
text: estimate effective reproduction number (Rt), pika function estimate_rt() provides wrapper EpiEstim::estimate_R() [3] enables users estimate Rt grouping variable. input estimate_rt() takes data frame daily cases deaths group. pika includes example data set china_case_data.rda includes daily reported cases COVID-19 several provinces China 16 January 2020 24 March 2020. estimate Rt case data, user must specify data set dat = argument estimate_rt(). data set include three columns: date column (class ‘date’), grouping variable, value used estimate Rt (commonly cases, quantities can used, deaths). names columns input data set specified character strings grp_var =, date_var =, incidence_var = arguments. method used estimate Rt can changed using est_method = argument. argument takes following options: c("non_parametric_si","parametric_si","uncertain_si","si_from_data","si_from_sample"). methods require specifying mean standard deviation serial interval, parameters can set using si_mean = si_std = function arguments. default values si_mean = 6.48 si_std = 3.83 [4]. information methodology underlying EpiEstim::estimate_R look vignette help("estimate_R").
code: # to estimate them with pika, use estimate_rt() ------------------------------------------ rt_estimates <- estimate_rt(dat = china_case_data,                             grp_var = "province",                             date_var = "date",                             incidence_var = "cases"                             ) %>%   # a little data formatting--------------------------------------------------------------   mutate(province = to_snake_case(province)) %>%   select(-date_start) %>%   rename("date" = "date_end")

title: pika: A lightweight package for evaluating correlation between time series
text: determining relationship two time series sometimes interest determine lag correlation two time series highest, ’ll call optimal lag. determine optimal lag, two time series must first merged single data frame. using dplyr’s left_join() date province. can identify optimal lag calculating cross correlation two time series grouping variable different lags using cross_corr function. argument max_lag = specifies maximum lag test. example set 10 days. subset_date = argument allows user determine cross correlation two time series subset time window. optimal lag determined, must back date Rt estimates without impacting date movement variable.
code: # Join data sets together by date and province to determine cross correlation ----------- # for this we are using input rt estimates, not those estimated using pika::estimate_rt() data_joined <- left_join(rt_estimates,                          exante_movement_data,                          by = c("date","province")                          ) # # Determine lag with max cross correlation between Rt and movement ---------------------- lags <- cross_corr(dat = data_joined,                    date_var = "date",                    grp_var = "province",                    x_var = "r_mean",                    y_var = "movement",                    max_lag = 10,                    subset_date = "2020-02-15"                   )  # use min lag across groups ------------------------------------------------------------- my_lag <- min(lags$lag) # create lag date using max lag from cross_corr() --------------------------------------- data_joined_lag <- rt_estimates %>%   mutate(date = date + my_lag) %>%   left_join(., exante_movement_data, by = c("date", "province"))

title: pika: A lightweight package for evaluating correlation between time series
text: Sometimes, interest convert count variable time percent change based average value specified baseline period. Using calc_percent_change() users can specify baseline period used determine percent change count variable time series. function written application mobility data, percent change mobility time relative baseline interest. However, function can applied count type time series.
code: perc_change_data <- calc_percent_change(dat = exante_movement_data,                                         date_var = "date",                                         grp_var = "province",                                          count_var = "movement",                                          n_baseline_periods = 7)

title: pika: A lightweight package for evaluating correlation between time series
text: often interest determine relationship two time series, specifically rolling correlation. rolling_corr() function calculates rolling correlation two times series (x_var y_var) specified time window n =. , calculate biweekly rolling correlation Rt movement. Since data daily estimates Rt movement, set n = 14. data monthly wanted determine 6 month rolling correlation, set n = 6. output rolling_corr() data frame additional column added input dataset called “rolling_corr”. Depending value n, first n values “rolling_corr” NA. visualise rolling correlation, results rolling_corr() can plotted using plot_corr(). creates plot two time series rolling correlation facetted grouping variable. optional arguments change facet labels (facet_lables =), legend_labels (legend_labels =), add confidence bounds primary time series (x_var_lower = x_var_upper =), set maximum value y-axis (y_max =). code plots mean Rt estimates 95% confidence bands, movement index, biweekly correlation . also specify custom facet legend labels restrict y-axis maximum value 10.
code: # Determine rolling correlation between Rt and movement --------------------------------- data_corr <- rolling_corr(dat = data_joined_lag,                           date_var = "date",                           grp_var = "province",                           x_var = "r_mean",                           y_var = "movement",                           n = 14) # Plot Rt, movement, and correlation ---------------------------------------------------- my_labels <- c("beijing" = "Beijing", "guangdong" = "Guangdong", "henan" = "Henan",                "hong_kong_sar" = "Hong Kong SAR", "hubei" = "Hubei", "hunan" = "Hunan",                "zhejiang" = "Zhejiang") my_legend = c("Correlation", "Reproduction Number", "Movement")  plot_corr(dat = data_corr,           date_var = "date",           grp_var = "province",           x_var = "r_mean",           y_var = "movement",           x_var_lower = "r_q2.5",           x_var_upper = "r_q97.5",           facet_labels = my_labels,           legend_labels = my_legend,           y_max = 10           )

title: pika - Evaluate Correlation Between Time Series
text: pika lightweight R package evaluating correlation time series. developed MRC Centre Global Infectious Disease Analysis epidemiological applications, particularly studying relationships reproduction numbers (Rt) population mobility infectious disease outbreaks. package developed part research described : Ainslie KEC, Walters CE, Fu H, et al. Evidence initial success China exiting COVID-19 social distancing policy achieving containment. Wellcome Open Research. 2020;5:81. doi: 10.12688/wellcomeopenres.15843.2

title: pika - Evaluate Correlation Between Time Series
text: Cross-correlation analysis: Determine optimal lag two time series correlation highest Rolling correlation: Calculate time-varying correlation paired time series Reproduction number estimation: Wrapper around EpiEstim group-wise Rt estimation Percent change calculation: Convert count variables percent change relative baseline period Visualization tools: Plot time series correlation overlays lag distributions

title: pika - Evaluate Correlation Between Time Series
text: can install development version pika GitHub:

title: pika - Evaluate Correlation Between Time Series
text: use pika within orderly task, install drat repository:

title: pika - Evaluate Correlation Between Time Series
code: library(pika)  # Load example data data(china_case_data) data(exante_movement_data)  # Estimate reproduction number by province rt_estimates <- estimate_rt(   dat = china_case_data,   grp_var = "province",   date_var = "date",   incidence_var = "cases" )  # Join Rt estimates with mobility data data_joined <- dplyr::left_join(   rt_estimates,   exante_movement_data,   by = c("date_end" = "date", "province") )  # Determine optimal lag between Rt and movement lags <- cross_corr(   dat = data_joined,   date_var = "date_end",   grp_var = "province",   x_var = "r_mean",   y_var = "movement",   max_lag = 10 )  # Calculate rolling correlation data_corr <- rolling_corr(   dat = data_joined,   date_var = "date_end",   grp_var = "province",   x_var = "r_mean",   y_var = "movement",   n = 14 )  # Visualize results plot_corr(   dat = data_corr,   date_var = "date_end",   grp_var = "province",   x_var = "r_mean",   y_var = "movement" )

title: pika - Evaluate Correlation Between Time Series
text: pika includes example datasets COVID-19 pandemic China: china_case_data: Daily confirmed COVID-19 cases province (Jan 16 - Mar 24, 2020) exante_movement_data: Daily within-city movement index province (Jan 1 - Mar 24, 2020)

what: Convert a count variable into percent change relative to baseline — calc_percent_change
title: Convert a count variable into percent change relative to baseline — calc_percent_change
text: function converts count variable time percent change based average value specified baseline period. function written application mobility data, percent change mobility time relative baseline interest. However, function can applied count type time series.

title: Convert a count variable into percent change relative to baseline — calc_percent_change
code: calc_percent_change(   dat,   date_var = "date",   grp_var,   count_var,   n_baseline_periods = 7,   start_date = NULL )

title: Convert a count variable into percent change relative to baseline — calc_percent_change
text: dat data frame columns correspond count variable grouping variable date_var character string name date column (class "Date") grp_var character string column name dat used grouping variable count_var character string name count column, number trips n_baseline_periods Number periods calculate baseline average . example, time series days, n_baseline_periods = 7 baseline week. start_date start date baseline period (character string)

title: Convert a count variable into percent change relative to baseline — calc_percent_change
text: data frame additional column percent change relative baseline

title: Determine cross correlation between two time series for different lags — cross_corr
text: dat data frame columns correspond two time series grouping variable(s) date_var character string column name corresponds date variable date_var must specified subset_date null. grp_var character string column names dat used grouping variable(s) x_var primary time series (column dat) y_var secondary time series (column dat) max_lag integer value number lags perform cross correlation subset_date character string format date variable

title: Determine cross correlation between two time series for different lags — cross_corr
text: tibble lags grp_var

title: This function plots the two time series and correlation over time There are optional arguments for confidence bands on x_var and customisation of the maximum value of the y-axis and labels for the facets of grp_var — plot_corr

title: pika 0.2.0
text: Fixed bug estimate_rt() date_end calculated incorrectly Fixed bug plot_lag() renamed data frame used Fixed type checking rolling_corr() use inherits() instead class() Replaced deprecated summarise_at() modern summarise() calc_percent_change()

title: pika 0.2.0
text: Added pkgdown website https://mrc-ide.github.io/pika/ Added GitHub Actions workflows R-CMD-check pkgdown deployment

title: pika 0.2.0
text: Completely rewrote README comprehensive usage examples Added citation associated Wellcome Open Research paper Fixed vignette index entry title Added URL BugReports fields DESCRIPTION

title: pika 0.2.0
text: Added comprehensive test coverage functions Added happy path tests cross_corr(), rolling_corr(), estimate_rt(), calc_percent_change() Added tests plot_lag() (previously untested) Added tests plot_corr() confidence bands customization options

title: pika 0.1.1
text: Added NEWS.md file track changes package. Added calc_percent_change() calculate percent change time series relative baseline period
